subtitle: Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove, and today I’d like to talk about
Kundalini phenomena. You know, my old friend Lee Sannella was an ophthalmologist – he also
practiced some psychiatry, as I recall – and he wrote a book that came out decades ago called Kundalini:
Psychosis or Transcendence?
He pointed out that the symptoms typically associated with what we now think of as kundalini
phenomenon were often misdiagnosed, in his opinion, as
psychotic symptoms. The idea is that at the base chakra,
the Muladhara chakra,
there’s coiled serpent energy, and sometimes that coiled serpent energy is also equated with the goddess
Shakti. So, the goddess
rises within us, this incredible,
potent, divine energy capable of doing many, many things in the world.
But sometimes it gets blocked, and when it gets blocked there are
symptoms that people experience:
energy running up and down the body for example, and a whole host of strange symptoms. Now,
it could be that this
phenomenology is the beginning of a very important spiritual, psychic breakthrough.
But, the psychiatry profession has no recognition of it. In
my own case, I’ve had three or four what I believe to be
relatively mild and benign kundalini
experiences. In my life they always seem to prompt me to explore
psychic and spiritual dimensions. For example,
when I was in the fifth grade, as I recall, one of my classmates in school, Lee
Rosenthal, decided to present a book report on a book he had just been reading – a popular book from the
1950s, The Search For Bridey Murphy. He got up in front of the class and he said, “You know, this book is
suggesting that we’ve lived before, that we have
previous lives.” When he mentioned that idea, I could feel this, like, tingling
sensation running up and down my spine. I was thinking, “Wow, previous lives, whew.”
The next time I had such an experience I was already in college. I was a college student
attending a summer
school program at the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee, and I was studying
play-writing as a matter of fact –
famous playwright Barrie Stavis was teaching the course as a guest professor.
I was, one day, sitting in the cafeteria
there at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee
campus, and some fellow came in the door and began passing out fliers.
I picked up a flier, and it said “Spiritual Science,” just those two words.
I hadn’t seen them juxtaposed that way before, and once again
tingling running up and down my spine,
in a positive way. I made a point – I attended the lecture that time and
got involved. I
became very friendly with the people from that organization, it was the Anthroposophical Society in America, a
spiriutal organization founded by the great Austrian
psychic Rudolf Steiner.
I don’t always get involved just because I’ve had a kundalini experience.
Another one, very powerful, occurred to me after
attending a session with Gurumayi, who was the head of a
Kashmir Shaivism yoga
organization founded by Swami Muktananda.
Gurumayi is, I guess most people would say, the successor to Swami Muktananda,
and she channels what she calls “Shaktipat” –
energy of Shakti – taps you on the forehead,
and it was a nice ceremony, and frankly I didn’t experience anything special at all that day. My wife,
who was with me, mentioned, “Gee, she wears nice hats.” But that night,
or a few nights later –
I’m not exactly sure – I had a dream in which Gurumayi came to me and tapped me on the forehead,
right in the third eye. And that time I felt
electricity, like you had taken a hundred and ten volts and
plugged it right into my forehead, and that was running up and down my spine. Very intense, very
powerful. It reminded me that I’ve had that experience one or two additional times in a dream.
But I can say in that instance it was
enough for me.
I never felt any further attraction to become involved in that organization. On the other hand, I
mentioned Dr. Lee Sannella earlier, the author of
Kundalini: Psychosis or
Transcendence?, and he became a devotee of a guru,
Franklin Jones – later known as Bubba Free John, later known as Da Love-Ananda and many other names –
[he] was a guru in the same tradition as
Muktananda and Gurumayi, in the sense that
he strongly maintained
that spiritual transmission comes from a master,
an enlightened being, and that’s why you need to have gurus.
Now, that’s not my philosophy but it’s theirs.
I have often felt that the best way to think of a guru is, “Gee, you are you.”
I’ve never really
joined any organization with a guru. It’s just not for me.
You could say I’m a secular spiritual person. But in any case,
Lee Sannella was a student of kundalini. I have
every reason to think, although he’s gone now for a long time, that his attraction
to that particular
organization – the Dawn Horse Communion, I believe it was called – was because of the idea of a kundalini
transmission. It’s something to be aware of. That is, I’m speaking to you as a scholar, a parapsychologist,
a seeker, an
experiencer, but not as a “Kundalini Master.” I
suspect that there are those who have vast knowledge
beyond my own. For example, my wife began having a kundalini experience.
It started spontaneously,
and it was bothersome to her, she wanted to turn it off, it got to the point
where it was unpleasant. I’ve never had that. Mine have all been pleasant. But, we found an ashram,
the Patanjali
Kundalini Care Ashram in Knoxville, Tennessee,
and she went there. The guru was there at the time, an eighty-year old swami from India,
and he talked to her and explained to her that the
shakti energy, the goddess, was stuck in a little
knot in one of the channels through which the energy flowed in her body.
He – within like twenty-four hours – he released it, it was gone, never came back again.
Although Janelle
has not become a devotee of that particular path, she was very grateful for what they did to her and for her.
So, how does
this have any impact on you? What’s the significance for you here? You can probably answer that question
already better than I could pose an additional question. Perhaps you’ve been having kundalini
experiences and knew that you were. Or, perhaps you’ve been having them
and they were treated or diagnosed as something else. Or, perhaps you’ve never had them and would like to.
Gopi Krishna has written a book about
kundalini experiences in which he claims that it is what underlies all great genius,
the activation of kundalini. So, perhaps it is something to be greatly desired,
although we don’t know what suffering some of these geniuses have gone through.
Or, perhaps you simply know people who are going through this, and you could be a
support person for them. Whatever it is for you, it’s worth, you know, giving some thought. Figure it out.
Where do you stand with regard to kundalini? You might think it’s all nonsense.
But then again, I
hope you’ll pay some attention, if you haven’t, to the
recent “In Presence” video I’ve made on “nonsense.” In any case, thank you for being with me.
